title-group.article-title: Community and domestic violence are associated with DNA methylation GrimAge acceleration and heart rate variability in adolescents

trans-title-group.trans-title: La violencia doméstica y comunitaria están asociadas con la aceleración de la metilación del ADN GrimAge y la variabilidad de la frecuencia cardíaca en adolescentes
社区和家庭暴力与青少年 DNA 甲基化 GrimAge 加速和心率变异性有关

title-group.alt-title: N. C. DOS SANTOS OLIVEIRA ET AL.

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Background: Cumulative exposure to violence can change the regulation of epigenetic and physiological markers. Although violence has been associated with accelerated cellular aging, little is known about associations with cardiac autonomic activity.
Objective: The current study aimed to investigate the relationship of exposure to community and domestic violence (CDV) with vagal activity and epigenetic aging acceleration.

Methods: A total of 86 adolescents (57% female) were evaluated and interviewed at two time-points in São Gonçalo (2014–2019), a Brazilian city with high levels of violence. Exposure to CDV was assessed in both time-points. GrimAge acceleration was calculated from saliva DNA methylation using Infinium HumanMethylation450K (Illumina) collected in the first assessment. Heart rate variability (HRV) was collected during two stress tasks at the second assessment.

Results: The exposure to violence witnessed or directly experienced at home and in the community increased significantly (t = 4.87, p < .01) across two-time points, and males had reported higher violence exposure (t = 2.06, p = .043). Violence at 1st assessment was significantly associated with GrimAge acceleration (B = .039, p value = .043). Violence at both assessments were associated with HRV measured during the narration of the worst trauma (traumaHRV) (B = .009, p value = .039, and B = .007, p value = .024, 1st and 2nd assessment respectively). GrimAge acceleration was significantly associated with traumaHRV (B = .043, p value = .049), and HRV measured during a 3D roller coaster video (B = .061, p value = .024).

Conclusions: We found relevant evidence that experiencing violence during adolescence is associated with epigenetic aging and stress-related vagal activity. Understanding these factors during this period could contribute to the development of early interventions for health promotion.

list-item.p: Higher exposure to Community and domestic violence is associated with increased GrimAge acceleration.
Higher GrimAge acceleration is associated with increased stress-related vagal activity.
Exposure to community and domestic violence increased significantly over time.

trans-abstract.p: Antecedentes: La exposición acumulativa a la violencia puede cambiar la regulación de los marcadores epigenéticos y fisiológicos. Aunque la violencia se ha asociado con el envejecimiento celular acelerado, se sabe poco acerca de las asociaciones con la actividad autonómica cardíaca.

p.sans-serif: El presente estudio tuvo como objetivo investigar la relación entre la exposición a la violencia doméstica y comunitaria (CDV por sus siglas en inglés) con la actividad vagal y la aceleración del envejecimiento epigenético.

trans-abstract.p: Métodos: Un total de 86 adolescentes (57% mujeres) fueron evaluados y entrevistados en dos momentos en São Gonçalo (2014–2019), una ciudad brasileña con altos niveles de violencia. La exposición a la violencia comunitaria y doméstica se evaluó en ambos momentos. La aceleración del GrimAge se calculó a partir de la metilación del ADN de la saliva, utilizando Infinium HumanMethylation450K (Illumina) recopilada en la primera evaluación. La variabilidad de la frecuencia cardíaca (HRV por sus siglas en inglés) se recogió durante dos tareas de estrés en la segunda evaluación.

Resultados: La exposición a la violencia presenciada o experimentada directamente en el hogar y en la comunidad aumentó significativamente (t = 4.87, p < .01) a lo largo de los dos momentos, los varones informaron una exposición mayor a la violencia (t = 2.06, p = .043). La violencia en la primera evaluación se asoció significativamente con la aceleración del GrimAge (B = 0.039, valour p = .043). La violencia en ambas evaluaciones se asoció con la HRV medida durante la narración del peor trauma (trauma HRV) (B = 0.009, valour p = .039, y B = 0.007, valour p = .024, primera y segunda evaluación respectivamente). La aceleración del GrimAge se asoció significativamente con trauma HRV (B = 0.043, valor p = .049) y la HRV medida durante un video de montaña rusa en 3D (B = 0.061, valor p = .024).

Conclusiones: Encontramos evidencia relevante de que experimentar violencia durante la adolescencia se asocia con el envejecimiento epigenético y la actividad vagal relacionada con el estrés. Comprender estos factores durante la adolescencia puede contribuir al desarrollo de intervenciones tempranas para la promoción de la salud.
背景：累积的暴力暴露可以改变表观遗传和生理标志物的调节。尽管暴力与加速细胞衰老有关，对于它与心脏自主神经活动的关联知之甚少。
目的：本研究旨在考查社区暴力和家庭暴力 (CDV) 暴露与迷走神经活动和表观遗传老化加速之间的关系。
方法：在一个高暴力的巴西城市圣贡萨洛，共有 86 名青少年（57% 为女性）在两个时间点（2014–2019 年）接受评估和访谈。在两个时间点都评估了 CDV 暴露。使用在第一次评估中使用 Infinium HumanMethylation450K (Illumina芯片) 收集的唾液 DNA 甲基化计算 GrimAge 加速。 在第二次评估时的两次压力任务期间收集心率变异性 (HRV)。

结果：在两个时间点上，在家庭和社区目睹或直接经历的暴力暴露显著增加 (t = 4.87，p < .01)，男性报告的暴力暴露更高 (t = 2.06，p = .043)。第一次评估时的暴力行为与 GrimAge 加速显著相关（B = .039，p = .043）。 两次评估中的暴力都与最严重创伤叙述期间测量的 HRV (traumaHRV) 相关（第一次和第二次评估分别为B = .009，p = .039，B = .007，p = .024）。 GrimAge 加速度与 traumaHRV（B = .043，p = .049）和 3D 过山车视频期间测量的 HRV 显著相关（B = .061，p = .024）。
结论：我们发现相关证据表明，在青春期经历暴力与表观遗传衰老和压力相关的迷走神经活动有关。 在青春期了解这些因素有助于制定早期健康促进干预措施。

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Violence and trauma experienced during childhood may accelerate the aging process (Jovanovic et al., 2017; Rampersaud et al., 2022) and increase the risk for cardiovascular disease, premature mortality, depression, anxiety, and posttraumatic stress disorder (Bahari et al., 2021; Murali & Chen, 2005). Epigenetic clocks are estimators based on DNA methylation (DNAm) to measure biological age, reflecting the impact of lifetime exposures (Horvath, 2013). Measures of epigenetic age acceleration are obtained by fitting the predicted DNAm age on chronological age, which reflect biological or cellular aging (Hannum et al., 2013; Horvath, 2013; Marioni et al., 2015). Studies with children and adolescents exposed to adversities have reported epigenetic age acceleration (Sumner, Colich, Uddin, Armstrong, & McLaughlin, 2019; Tang et al., 2020) and its association with alterations of brain volumes and cortical areas (Hoare et al., 2020). Adolescence is a sensitive period in the development of brain and behaviour (Knudsen, 2004). Therefore, understanding epigenetic aging can contribute to gaining a deeper comprehension of the critical role that violence plays in developmental trajectories, in order to improve early and preventative interventions for health promotion.

A recent epigenetic clock DNAm GrimAge (Lu et al., 2019) has been proposed as a useful biomarker of cardiovascular health risk for early detection and prevention (Joyce et al., 2021). Although cardiovascular disease has also been associated with other epigenetic clocks such as Hannum, Horvath, and Levine (Oblak et al., 2021), GrimAge is suggested to outperform these clocks in the prediction of functional health measures as a robust epigenetic aging marker (McCrory et al., 2021). For a review about the epigenetic clock, see Oblak et al. (2021). Evidence for GrimAge accelerated aging has been shown in adolescents and young children with fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (mean age 11 years old) (Okazaki et al., 2021), obesity (from 8 to 14 years old) (Etzel et al., 2022), as well as significant changes in GrimAge component in children (from 5 months to 3 years old) with Zika virus microcephaly (Nwanaji-Enwerem et al., 2021). GrimAge estimator has not yet been investigated with adolescents exposed to violence, and little is known about the relationship of DNAm with stress-related physiological responses (Oliveira et al., 2021).

Violence may affect cardiovascular health through changes in stress-related physiological responses that might lead to future health problems, such as hypertension, coronary heart disease, and myocardial infarction (Suglia et al., 2015; Tyra et al., 2021). DNA methylation is suggested as a biological mechanism involved in the effects of trauma and violence on cardiovascular activity (Giurgescu et al., 2019; Oliveira et al., 2021; Zannas et al., 2019). For instance, children with higher epigenetic aging had twice as much violence exposure, showing reduced heart rate (Jovanovic et al., 2017). Here we focused on the exposure to violence witnessed or directly experienced at home and in the community by adolescents, known as community and domestic violence. Lifetime exposure to community and domestic violence was already associated with differences in BDNF methylation in adolescents (Serpeloni et al., 2020), a key player in the regulation of cardiovascular system (Pius-Sadowska & Machaliński, 2017), and development of psychiatric disorders (D’Addario et al., 2012). Multigenerational epigenetic effects in response to violence have been reported in methylation of genes involved in cardiovascular system development (Serpeloni et al., 2017).

The present study also investigates stress-related physiological responses using heart rate variability (HRV), a non-invasive measure of autonomic cardiac activity (Shaffer & Ginsberg, 2017). HRV reflects the dynamic of both autonomic nervous system (ANS) branches in cardiac activity and has been supported as a reliable measure for assessing psychological health and stress (Kim et al., 2018). Nonetheless, few studies have investigated the association between DNAm and HRV. For instance, Aghagoli et al. (2020) reported that increased DNAm in infants exposed to a social stressor was associated with higher parasympathetic activity, while Lancaster et al. (2018) found that increased DNAm was associated with lower HRV in fear-related responses.

Here we aim to investigate the association of exposure to domestic and community violence with epigenetic aging and vagal tone activity. For this purpose, GrimAge acceleration and HRV in response to stress tasks were assessed at two time points. We hypothesized that those who have experienced more violence would have lower HRV and higher epigenetic aging acceleration. We also expect HRV to be associated with epigenetic aging acceleration.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: This cohort represents a subset of a larger project (N = 386) that investigates the epigenetic effects of maternal stress during pregnancy on DNA methylation across three generations (Serpeloni et al., 2017). The data collection was conducted at two time points (2014 and 2019) in São Gonçalo (Rio de Janeiro state, Brazil), where children and adolescents report experiencing high levels of community and domestic violence (Pinto & Gonçalves de Assis, 2013). For the present study, the third generation (126 children) was contacted from the original cohort, and 91 adolescents agreed to participate. Five participants were excluded from the present study: Three did not fulfil health conditions for HRV measures (decompensated heart failure, heart arrhythmia and pregnancy), one due to a technical problem with the HRV measurement, and one had DNA methylation data with low detection signals that were excluded by the quality control pipeline. In total, 86 participants (57% female) were included in the study. At the first assessment the average age was 13 (range: 8–19), and at the second assessment the average age was 18 (range: 13–24). The study was approved by the National Research Ethics Commission (CONEP/57444416.6.0000.5240). Written informed consent from the adult participants, written informed consent from parents, and written assent from the adolescents were obtained. Participation was voluntary, and no monetary compensation was provided.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p:
Exposure to domestic and community violence events, sociodemographic information including participant`s age and sex, as well as HRV and saliva samples were collected. Local interviewers were trained and supervised throughout the data collection. Structured interviews were conducted at the participant’s house in both assessments. Saliva samples were collected in the first assessment (Serpeloni et al., 2017), and HRV was recorded in the second assessment (see Figure 1). For the HRV acquisition, participants were asked not to drink energy drinks or undergo vigorous physical activity 12 h before the evaluation (Catai et al., 2020). After receiving a detailed explanation of the procedures and filling out consent forms, the Firstbeat heart rate belt was attached to the abdomen according to the manufacturer’s instruction. Participants were sitting during the interview without any sudden movements. Figure 1.
Flowchart of the procedure across two time points. CDV: Community domestic violence. HRV: Heart rate variability.

sec.title: Community and domestic violence (CDV)
sec.p: Exposure to CDV was assessed using the ‘Things I have seen and heard’ questionnaire (Richters & Martinez, 1990). This scale measures different types of violence both witnessed and directly experienced at home and in the community. Items are presented in a five-point Likert scale format ranking from zero (never) to four (many times). Higher scores reflect higher exposure to violence (Cronbach’s α = 0.71; possible range 0–88). The same questionnaire was applied at both time points. The score at the first assessment reflects experiences of violence from childhood to adolescence, while the second assessment reflects what happened during the five years after the first assessment. A lifetime measure of CDV was created by summing CDV scores from the first and second assessments.

sec.title: GrimAge acceleration
sec.p: Details for data collection, as well as DNAm processing and validation, can be found here (Serpeloni et al., 2017). Briefly, DNA was extracted from saliva collected with the Oragene self-collection kit (DNA Genotek, ON, Canada) and interrogated using Infinium HumanMethylation450 BeadChip (Illumina) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The raw methylation beta values were reprocessed in this study. Samples with probe detection call rates of less than 90% and those with an average intensity value of either less than 50% of the experiment-wide sample mean or less than 2000 arbitrary units were removed using R package CpGassoc (1 sample was removed) (Barfield et al., 2012). Probes with detection p-values of more than 0.01 were set to missing and probes missing for more than 10% of the samples were filtered out. CpG sites that cross-hybridize between autosomes and sex chromosomes were removed (Chen et al., 2013). Single-sample Noob (ssNoob) background correction was used for normalization (Triche et al., 2013). ComBat procedure was used to remove batch effects of chip and position (Leek et al., 2012). GrimAge and GrimAge acceleration (age-adjusted version of GrimAge) estimates were obtained from the DNA methylation age calculator (Lu et al., 2019). GrimAge acceleration is the residual from regressing epigenetic age on chronological age (Protsenko et al., 2021). Robust partial correlation algorithm implemented in Epidish package was used to estimate the proportions of epithelial, fibroblast, and the immune cells (Zheng et al., 2018). Estimated proportions of epithelial cells were included as covariate in multiple regression models.

sec.title: Heart rate variability (HRV)
sec.p: HRV was continuously recorded with a wireless Polar™ cardiac monitor, the V800 model. HRV acquisition was performed following the same sequence of tasks for all participants. Four different conditions were evaluated: (a) neutral speech – the first 3 min of the interview, which consisted of sociodemographic questions; (b) neutral video – composed by a 3-minutes slideshow of 26 neutral images obtained from the international image bank IAPS (International Affective Picture System), according to recommendations composite of activation and valence scores (Lang et al., 2008); (c) trauma narration – narration of the worst lifetime traumatic event using the UCLA trauma questionnaire (Mean = 3 min) (Steinberg et al., 2004); and (d) emotional arousal video – to estimate stress-induced physiological arousal regulation, a 3D virtual-reality video of a roller coaster ride, played on a smartphone in a Google Cardboard headset (3 min). The video was chosen from YouTube and evaluated by our research group. Between baseline neutral speech and narration of the worst trauma, as well as between neutral and arousal video, there was a mean of 23 min. A second and different neutral video was presented after the trauma narration task for recovery, followed by the arousal video. Between trauma narration task and arousal video, there were approximately 5 min. The second neutral video was developed according to the same guidelines as the first one. The centre 2-minute period for each condition and consecutive heartbeat R-R intervals of the whole heart rhythm recording were selected using Kubios HRV® software (Tarvainen et al., 2014). A threshold-based correction algorithm with a medium filter was applied to discriminate and remove artefacts (Alcantara et al., 2020). The present study focuses on the root mean square of successive differences (rMSSD) metric, which reflects vagal tone activity through parasympathetic-branch-mediated changes in HRV (Laborde et al., 2018; Shaffer et al., 2014). Corresponding conditions were used: (i) speech (trauma narration vs. neutral speech); and (ii) condition without speech (roller-coaster video vs. neutral video). TraumaHRV was calculated by dividing rMSSD of the trauma narration by the that of the neutral speech. ArousalHRV was calculated by dividing rMSSD of the roller-coaster ride video by that of the neutral video. Both parameters of HRV were logarithmically transformed prior to subsequent analyses. Sex was included as a covariate in all models to adjust for differences in the autonomic control of the heart (Koenig & Thayer, 2016).

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: We performed the Student’s T-test to compare difference in mean of exposure to violence across time and sex differences. To assess the performance of the GrimAge clock in saliva samples, we examined the correlation between chronological age and GrimAge. We then calculated bivariate correlations of CDV at first assessment with GrimAge acceleration and CDV at both assessments with HRV.

Subsequently, multiple linear regression models were used to investigate the relationship between experiences of violence, GrimAge acceleration, and HRV. Sex and proportions of epithelial cells were included as covariates in all models involving GrimAge acceleration. Sex and age for associations between HRV and CDV. P values < .05 were considered statistically significant. All statistical analyses were performed using R Software (version 4.1.3; R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria).

sec.title: Community and domestic violence (CDV)
sec.p:
The sample demographics and levels of exposure to CDV at first and second assessments are shown in Table 1. CDV increased over time (t = 4.87, p < .01), and showed a significant sex difference, with males being exposed to more violence than females (t = 2.06, p = .043, Table 1). CDV distribution also demonstrated significant intra-individual correlation between the first and second assessments (r = .64, p value = 2.5e-11, Supplementary Figure 1). Participants reported having experienced an average of 29.19 (SD = 16.94, range: 4–95) lifetime exposure to CDV. All participants were exposed to some violence experience and reported experiencing community and domestic violence more than four times throughout their lifetime. Table 1.
Participant’s characteristics (n = 86).

sec.title: CDV and heart rate variability (HRV)
sec.p:
The mean of HRV indicated higher parasympathetic activity during arousal video (M = 1.09, SD = 0.35) than observed during the trauma narration (M = .95, SD = .28; t = 2.77, p < .01; Figure 2). The HRV ratio value > 1 (or < 1) indicates that parasympathetic activity is higher (or lower) than observed in the neutral condition. Therefore, the arousal video generated a higher activation level of the parasympathetic autonomic system, while there was less activation during the trauma narration. Figure 2.
HRV during the trauma narration and arousal video. The HRV ratio value > 1 (or < 1) indicates that parasympathetic activity is higher (or lower) than observed in the neutral condition. The parasympathetic activation was significantly higher during the arousal video compared to trauma narration.

TraumaHRV was positively correlated with CDV at the second assessment (r = .23, p value = .03, Supplementary Figure 2), but not during the first assessment (r = .2, p = .06, Supplementary Figure 2). However, the associations between traumaHRV and CDV at both time points were significant in multiple linear regression analysis adjusted for age and sex (ß = .009, p value = .039, and ß = .007, p value = .024, 1st and 2nd assessment respectively, Table 2, Figure 3(A,B)). While ArousalHRV was not correlated with any CDV measure (r = .16, p value = .15 and r = .17, p value = .11, 1st and 2nd assessment respectively, Supplementary Figure 2). Figure 3.
Scatterplot illustrating the associations of (A) traumaHRV with CDV 1st assessment, and (B) CDV 2nd assessment, as well as the associations of GrimAge acceleration with (C) community and domestic violence (CDV) at 1st assessment, (D) traumaHRV, (E) arousalHRV. Gray shaded area represents 95% confidence region. Table 2.

sec.title: CDV, GrimAge acceleration and HRV
sec.p: DNAm GrimAge was correlated with the chronological age (r = .6, p = 9.7e-10, Supplementary Figure 3). Participants who experienced a higher level of CDV at first assessment had higher GrimAge acceleration (B = .039, p value = .043, Table 2 and Figure 3(C)). Higher GrimAge acceleration has been positively associated with increases in levels of both HRV conditions evaluated: traumaHRV (B = .043, p value = .049, Figure 3(D)), and arousalHRV (B = .061, p value = .024) (see Table 2 and Figure 3(E)).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we examined 86 participants assessed at two time points. The results showed that higher exposure to community and domestic violence (CDV) is associated with higher GrimAge acceleration and increases in HRV measured while narrating a traumatic event and watching a 3D roller-coaster ride video.

Our results showed that increased GrimAge acceleration is associated with greater exposure to CDV in adolescents. This finding is consistent with previous reports in adults and children that higher experiences of violence increased epigenetic aging (Jovanovic et al., 2017; Katrinli et al., 2020). Adversity exposures during sensitive periods in childhood have been related to changing methylation processes in ways that either directly or indirectly perturb normal cellular aging, and these effects may be heightened during specific life stages (Marini et al., 2020). Epigenetic age acceleration has also been associated with adverse health outcomes, such as shorter gestational length and lower birthweight (Ross et al., 2020), depressive disorder (Protsenko et al., 2021), cognitive impairment in bipolar disorder (Lima et al., 2022), as well as mortality, cancer, diabetes and cardiovascular disease (Oblak et al., 2021). This study highlights the importance of considering the aging process associated with violence exposure and calls attention for the development of early interventions to guarantee a health development.

Our results extend previous findings by exploring the association of epigenetic aging acceleration with HRV. HRV is a reliable indicator of psychological stress, and represents the degree to which the autonomic nervous system adapts to environmental and physiological stimuli through regulating cardiovascular processes (Kim et al., 2018). Consistent with the stress reactivity literature, HRV was found to decrease during the narration of the worst trauma (Seddon et al., 2020). Decreased HRV has been shown, for instance, in individuals with anxiety disorder (Held, Vîslă, Wolfer, Messerli-Bürgy, & Flückiger, 2021) and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) (Keary et al., 2009). However, HRV measured during the arousal video showed a different pattern due to a significant increase of HRV. It appears that narrating the worst trauma elicited more physiological heart rate arousal than watching a 3D roller-coaster video. Indeed, emotion activation associated with trauma narration is a key element in trauma-focused therapy (Schauer, Neuner, & Elbert, 2011). The results might also indicate suppression of parasympathetic activity during trauma narration when compared with the arousal video, which would imply in withdrawal and up-regulation of vagal tone. The findings bring the discussion of individuals’ autonomic flexibility or ability to adjust parasympathetic activity in each condition. A physiological state characterized by increased vagal influence on the heart would support spontaneous social engagement behaviours, while the vagal withdrawal would support the mobilization behaviours of fight and flight (Porges, 2007). The modulation of vagal tone is known as an autonomic regulation important for cardiovascular health, and deficient vagal inhibition could be implicated in increased morbidity (Thayer et al., 2010). Parasympathetic arousal has also been associated with heightened attention and well-being, specifically, the increase of vagal tone facilitates attention and optimal mental health (Barber et al., 2020; Messerli-Bürgy et al., 2020; Mestanikova et al., 2019). Also, greater HRV appears to be a physiological indicator of adaptive emotion regulation and decreased mental load (Denson et al., 2011). As a limitation, the hypothesis that the arousal video has not worked as a stress inducer should be considered. Whether HRV in our sample reflects individual’s capacity to adapt effectively to changing social or environmental contexts remains to be investigated (Beauchaine, 2001; Berntson et al., 2008).

We expected that decreased HRV (parasympathetic activation) during the narration of worst trauma would be associated with greater epigenetic aging. In contrast, we found a parasympathetic dominance in HRV among those adolescents with increased GrimAge acceleration. Higher GrimAge acceleration was significantly associated with increases in both HRV conditions. Increased parasympathetic activity has also been reported by Chou et al. (2018) during dissociation experienced over trauma recall among individuals with PTSD. This confers a parasympathetically dominated shut-down peritraumatic response to the traumatic event (Schauer & Elbert, 2010). We have not measured dissociative symptoms. Future studies investigating epigenetic aging responses to dissociation, might shed light in the understanding of trauma-related disorders.

While these results are of interest, limitations of our study should be highlighted: Respiratory rate was not measured in the present study; however, rMSSD seems to be less affected by the respiratory rate (Hill & Siebenbrock, 2009), and more appropriate for spontaneous breathing (Melo et al., 2018). Mainly when data are recorded in a non-laboratory environment, which permits spontaneous breathing (Penttilä et al., 2001). Additionally, rMSSD performed better as a marker of parasympathetic activity when the task required breathing changes (Thomas et al., 2019). DNA methylation was measured from saliva samples. Although the GrimAge estimator was developed on blood samples, it has shown consistent results in saliva-derived DNA methylation in PTSD (Mehta et al., 2021). Measures of HRV and DNA methylation were collected in distinguished time points. Although we observed an association between violence, HRV, and accelerated epigenetic aging in adolescents, the cross-sectional nature of our data prevents addressing mechanism and causality. We have focused the analysis on the association of violence exposure, epigenetic acceleration, and HRV. We have shown that these variables are significantly associated without correcting for any other variable than age and sex. Exploring the association with other variables should be warranted in new studies. Replication of these results in larger samples is recommended. Further longitudinal studies might validate the corresponding epigenetic aging and physiological outcomes. In addition, GrimAge used a training and test dataset with older individuals from the Framingham Heart Study (Lu et al., 2019) than the participants in our study. Therefore, the relation between GrimAge morbidity and mortality age in younger populations still needs to be specified. However, this does not change the relation found between GrimAge acceleration with higher experiences of violence, and increased heart rate variability.

In conclusion, exposure to community and domestic violence was associated with GrimAge acceleration and stress-related vagal activity. Furthermore, GrimAge acceleration showed an association with stress-related vagal activity. The results contribute to the development of a more comprehensive molecular and physiological model of trauma responses, and further emphasize the importance of the development of early interventions to address the health problems associated with violence exposure. The current study findings also revealed a cumulative experience of violence in young age, expanding a significant body of research that has yielded similar findings. Although our study assists in revealing the interplay between epigenetic and physiological markers related to exposure to violence, the mechanism linking these findings deserves further investigation.

caption.p: Click here for additional data file.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We are grateful to all participants for making this study possible. We are also thankful to Prof. Dr. Eliane Volchan and Prof. Dr. Michel Reis for the valuable insights into the study.

sec.title: Disclosure statement
sec.p: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: The R script of our analysis data is available in ‘figshare' at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.21614241.v1. It must be noted that the Brazilian raw data can be acquired by contacting the main authors of this paper, but will be subjected to individual written consents, and assurance that all research done on the material will follow the ethical protocols.
